bibl.title: Ng Key Tung vs. Henry M. White. Criminal.

org.orgName: Western District Court of the United States, Northern Division.

div1.p: UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT WESTERN DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON NORTHERN DIVISION
IN RE THE APPLICATION OF NG KEW TUNG, FOR ADMISSION TO THE UNITED STATES. ) No. 2897. Filed January 21, 1915.
APPLICATION FOR HABEAS CORPUS WRIT DENIED.
Daniel Landon ) William T. Laube ) For Applicant
Clay Allen, U. S. District Atty.) For Government. George F. Fishburne, Asst. )

A Chinese boy, fifteen years of age, claiming to be the son of a resident Chinaman, was refused admission to the United States by Henry M. White, Immigration Commissioner. Appeal was taken to the Secretary of Commerce and Labor and the decision of the Commissioner affirmed. Get Tock, a Chinese merchant of Walla Walla, Washington, claimed to be the father of the boy, and made application for a writ of habeas corpus, alleging, among other irregularities, that the finding was not sustained by the evidence, and that the proceeding was not fairly conducted.
This court said in Ex Parte Moola Singh, et al, 207 Fed. 708, at page 782:

"The authority of the Immigration officers and the jurisdiction of the courts depend upon power conferred by Congress. It is a matter of legislation. No discretion is vested in the courts. Congress has the right to legislate upon the subject; prescribe rules; fix limits, and confer authority where it deems wise, in legislating upon the subject at hand. The Supreme authority is conferred upon the Immigration officers. The jurisdiction of the court is limited to ascertaining whether the petitioners were denied a hearing."

An examination of the record shows, to my mind, that the applicant was given a fair and impartial hearing. It is contended that the conclusion of the Immigration officers based upon the testimony presented, was wrong and not warranted. The court has not the power to examine the testimony with a view of --1--
determining whether the court would arrive at the same conclusion. That is a matter which is limited to the Immigration officers. The court's inquiry is limited as to whether the applicant was accorded an impartial hearing, and the court could not inquire into the sufficiency of probaitve facts or consider reasons for the conclusions reached by the Immigration officers. White v. Greggory, 213 Fed. 768.
The petition for writ is denied.
IN THE DISTRICT COURT OF THE UNITED STATES FOR THE WESTERN DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON NORTHERN DIVISION
FILED IN THE U. S. District Court, Western Dist. of Washington, NORTHERN DIVISION JAN211915
div1.ab: FRANK L. CROSBY, Clerk, By EML Deputy
